The digital Bayern Atlas is a patchwork that cannot be seen as such .
More detailed maps , so-called original position sheets , were incorporated into the large overview map for cities and municipalities .
These were created according to the Bavarian survey administration between 1810 and 1864 and originated from the first survey of Bavaria .
Your client : Napoleon .
The French Army leader occupied Bavaria with Austria since the spring of 1800 during the Second Coalition War .
Napoleon wanted an overview of the occupied country and commissioned a topographic admission of Bavaria - for military purposes , of course .
Although the French troops finally departed with Lunéville 's peace of 9 February 1801 , it was today 's neighbours who created the idea of a comprehensive Bavaria map .
Kurfürst Max IV Joseph pushed the project forward , founded the " Topographic Bureau " - and thus the Bavarian survey administration .
The original position sheet for Munich dates back to 1856 and can be found on the website of the Bavarian State Library , like all others .
The comparison of the past / present is most impressive , for example , in the state capital .
The city has expanded in all directions and has grown together .
An example of this is the Untersendling , which appears relatively isolated in the map of 1856 .
Sendling was incorporated into Munich as a quarter 21 years after the map was created in 1877 .
Today , Untersendling lies in the heart of the city .

Now Trump ’ s White House Takes the Statue of Liberty
The safest sign of regime change is when they begin to attack the statues .
Americans appreciate it , as do anyone else , so the carefully staged overthrow of Saddam Hussein in Baghdad ’ s Firdos Square in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , certainly knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe into the status of freedom in a heated dispute with Jim Acosta of CNN about the president ’ s proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A Horde of boat owners and Liberty Imitators would have laughed him if he had done so .

But he attacked their meaning , and in particular the importance attributed to it , when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added to his base in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument .
As Miller Acosta accused : " I do not want to go into a complete thing about history here , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that enlightens the world .
The poem to which you refer , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty . '
Miller is factually right , but as he himself put it , it is not really about history .

It is about the contemporary response to Lazarus 's shocking words , the only one in which a state not only invites any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your wives , your poor , / your crowded masses who yearn to breathe freely , / the miserable waste of your rich coasts . '
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' on our screens was better seen .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict , because of the importance of a statue , is part of a broader political and cultural struggle : it is indeed a conflict over the importance of America .
Lazarus - and her friends who worked to place their words at the base after their death - knew very well that they were carrying out a highly political act .
The sculpture was supposed to show the connections between French and American Republicanism by portraying the feminine embodiment of freedom in an abused classical depiction .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem the female figure is no longer abstract - she received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : Mother of the exiles .
The connection of poetry with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people from the right wing wanted to change it back for a long time .

The great cry of Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty is not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative that brings the American flame to the surrounding world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It is supposed to carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch is not supposed to light the way to the United States . '
Quite unusual is Limbaugh here .
The significance of the statue is entirely a question of the point of view of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see them as they were seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the deck of ships .
It is truly a matter of seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome that they have to hear .
And that , of course , is not the perspective that Miller and Trump ever want to recognize .
Their torch is not supposed to enlighten the way , but to inflame the hatred that is their only source of power .

Poverty and Death in Indonesia ’ s Goldland
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It even seldom uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai Regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the chopped bone is taken out with diligent , unwashed hands and swallowed .
Degei sits on the clay floor - she does not have any furniture - where she also performs her daily work , for example washing clothes with cloudy water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of the four wives of her husband , she was not assigned fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , working late can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around the village after 5 p.m. ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony , which was admitted in 1969 after a disputed referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were to vote by means of a public handshake before the occupying forces .
An existing movement that stirred up independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the government of Jakarta , which controls the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea encompassing the eastern part of the island .
The trip includes a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire and then a 5-hour car ride in the morning .
There is no public transport .
The city , with approximately 19,000 inhabitants , consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated roofs , which were converted into different yellow brown tones by rust .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and practically no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not accustomed to wearing these clothes ,  Degei says , pointing to her lively , handwoven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
'In the past we had only leaves on our bodies ' .
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s goldland .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by Freeport McMoran of Phoenix , is only 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province of the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport lost $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
Moreover , Papua has wood resources worth an estimated $ 78 billion .
These riches , however , are a source of misery for the Papua people to ensure that Indonesia ’ s powerful military maintains a stifling presence .
A 2005 survey in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid nearly $ 20 million to local military personnel and units between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten these golden gans and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal highlands in the 1970 ’ s became genocide according to the Asia Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We will lose all  is said in a 2016 report by the Archdiocese of Brisbane , which contains reports of atrocities of the previous year , such as illegal executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal repression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims because incidents happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian researcher for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have increased , as Papua 's resources generate an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

The population of 3.5 million inhabitants of the province is 83 % Christian , but demographic development is changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java , Borneo , Sumatra and Sulawesi .
Javanese Warung canteens sell fried chicken and Gado-Gado , a mixed vegetables served with peanut sauce .
Local people are fighting to keep up here .

Migrants have begun to sell chickens and vegetables on the traditional market cheaper than local Papua ,  explains Abeth You , a 24-year-old Paniai natives who moved to the provincial capital of Jayapura .
'It has cost the indigenous Papua - the Mama Mama [ the women ] of Papua - their market . '
Indonesian President Joko Widodo , popularly known as Jokowi , promised to address the inequalities and violations of the law in Papua during his 2014 campaign .
The former carpenter secured 27 of Papua 's 29 districts - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today the locals feel cheated .
Our hearts are broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 , with the expectation that he will meet our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says you .
Indeed , Paniai suffered a low point only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children was out and sang Christmas songs in front of a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through the dark on a motorcycle .
The frightened children told them that they should turn their headlights on .
One of the soldiers took offence at their tone and came back later with four soldiers , according to the local pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their rifles , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
A child , the 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was hit so hard that he fell into coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was set on fire and things escalated the next day .
About 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered on a football pitch in front of the local police station and the military command centre to demand justice .
They carried out ceremonial hunting arches and performed the Waita dance - in a circle and imitating a bird song - by Papuas Mee Pago tribe .
Some demonstrators began to throw stones on police and military posts .

When the mood was heated , the soldier was sent a command of an internal radio : " If the masses resist more than three times , they shoot them dead , " it is said in an official TIME document that was not released to the local media .
